form.current-chamber: IN THE SENATE OF THE UNITED STATES

action.action-desc: Mr. Vitter introduced the following bill; which was read twice and referred to the Committee on the Judiciary

form.official-title: To amend chapter 44 of title 18, United States Code, to update certain procedures applicable to commerce in firearms and remove certain Federal restrictions on interstate firearms transactions.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Firearms Interstate Commerce Reform Act.

section.header: Authority to conduct interstate firearms transactions

subsection.text: Section 922(b)(3)(A) of title 18, United States Code, is amended—

paragraph.text: by striking rifle or shotgun and inserting firearm;
by striking located and inserting located or temporarily located; and
by striking both such States and inserting the State in which the transfer is conducted and the State of residence of the transferee.

subsection.text: Section 923 of such title is amended—

subparagraph.text: in the first sentence, by striking , and such location is in the State which is specified on the license; and

clause.text: by inserting transfer, after sell,; and
by striking all that follows Act and inserting a period; and

paragraph.text: by adding at the end the following:

subsection.text: Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to prohibit the sale, transfer, delivery, or other disposition of a firearm or ammunition—

paragraph.text: by a person licensed under this chapter to another person so licensed, at any location in any State; or
by a licensed importer, licensed manufacturer, or licensed dealer to a person not licensed under this chapter, at a temporary location described in subsection (j) in any State.

subsection.text: Section 921 of such title is amended by striking subsection (b) and inserting the following:

paragraph.text: A member of the Armed Forces on active duty, or a spouse of the member, is a resident of—

subparagraph.text: the State in which the person maintains legal residence;
the State in which the permanent duty station of the member is located; and
the State in which the member maintains a place of abode from which the member commutes each day to the permanent duty station.

paragraph.text: An officer or employee of the United States (other than a member of the Armed Forces) stationed outside the United States for a period exceeding one year, or a spouse residing with such an officer or employee, is a resident of the State in which the person maintains legal residence.
